findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `blacklistAddress` function.

findings.title: PAV - Pair Address Validation
findings.description: The contract lacks address validation in the pair address argument, which can introduce security risks and potential attacks.

findings.title: GO - Gas Optimization
findings.description: The `swapAndLiquify` function executes multiple token swaps, consuming gas and leading to increased gas costs, especially when multiple swaps are triggered within a single transaction.

findings.title: FRV - Fee Restoration Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract demonstrates a potential vulnerability upon removing and restoring the fees. This can occur when the fees have been set to zero, leading to unintended consequences, potentially causing incorrect fee calculations or unexpected behavior within the contract.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: EPC - Existing Pair Creation
findings.description: The contract contains a function that does not handle the scenario where a pair already exists prior to its execution.

findings.title: TUU - Time Units Usage
findings.description: The contract is using arbitrary numbers to form time-related values, decreasing readability and preventing compiler optimization.

findings.title: RRS - Redundant Require Statement
findings.description: The contract utilizes a `require` statement within the `add` function aiming to prevent overflow errors. This redundancy could lead to extra gas costs and increased complexity without providing additional security.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and later have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: RSK - Redundant Storage Keyword
findings.description: The contract uses the `storage` keyword in a view function. The `storage` keyword is used to persist data on the contract's storage. View functions are functions that do not modify the state of the contract and do not perform any actions that cost gas (such as sending a transaction). As a result, the use of the `storage` keyword in view functions is redundant.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L08 - Tautology or Contradiction
findings.description: Using tautologies or contradictions can lead to unintended behavior and make the code harder to understand and maintain.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.
